Award.AwardTitle: Multiscale Structure-Mechanical Property Investigation of Additive Manufactured Components for Development of a Reliable Qualification Method

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Additive manufacturing (also called 3D printing) is now capable of producing/building complex-shaped metal components strong enough for structural applications. However, standard qualification methods for traditional manufacturing are not suitable for additive manufactured parts because the mechanical behavior of these parts is fundamentally different from those made by traditional means. Hence, the goal of this research is to develop a highly reliable, low-cost, and efficient qualification method for additive manufactured components based on a combined approach of validated computer simulations and non-destructive evaluation techniques. This qualification method will potentially lead to much wider adoption of additive manufacturing and will impact applications requiring complex, high value, time-sensitive, and customized products and prototypes such as automobile and aerospace parts (i.e., complex designs), broken part replacement (i.e. time-sensitive), and medical implants (i.e., highly customized). The skills and knowledge the students gain in this project will prepare them for active roles in securing the the United States' leadership in manufacturing engineering for future generations.

To achieve its goal, this project has the following objectives: 1) Characterize key microstructure features and mechanical properties across multiple length scales; 2) Develop a probabilistic constitutive model to capture sub-micron mechanical behavior; 3) Develop a macroscopic model based on microstructure data from various non-destructive evaluation techniques; and 4) Test the qualification method on a complex part. This research tackles a challenging problem in the reliable qualification of additive manufactured structural components whose local microstructure and mechanical behavior may vary widely among different builds of the same component. The utilization of X-ray micro computed tomography guarantees that any microscale flaws in the materials being scanned can be detected so that direct simulation of their mechanical behavior in the design component is possible. Through the multiscale investigation, a constitutive model will be developed to capture the mechanical effects of flaws, grain size, and residual stress. The integration of various nondestructive evaluation techniques with physics-based modeling will thus enable a rapid, reliable, and low-cost qualification method for additive manufactured components.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research supported by this grant has resulted in three conference presentations and seven published journal articles.  In this project, the most important gap of knowledge addressed was the origin of the different grain textures and phase transformation observed experimentally in metals produced by additively manufacturing (AM, commonly known as 3D printing) metals, particularly how the process parameters affect the melt pool geometry and yield certain grain texture and mechanical properties. This gap of knowledge was addressed through theoretical modeling of the process-microstructure-property relationship of an AM metal.  The utilization of rigorous physical and mechanics principles including heat transfer in the melt pool, solidification microstructure theory, and polycrystal plasticity theory ensures that the resulting process-microstructure-property model is easily verifiable, transferable, and extensible. Although the modeling efforts in this project were focused on aluminum and titanium alloys, the proposed model is physics-based and sufficiently general that it can be easily adapted to other AM-processed crystalline metals. Ultimately, the model established will potentially enable an efficient simulation-based qualification method for AM metallic components.

The knowledge gained in the process-microstructure-property relationship for AM metals will potentially lead to a much wider adoption of the AM process by the manufacturing industry, because 1) the process parameters and microstructural features of an AM component can be tailored to suit specific grain structure and mechanical performance requirements without the need for extensive experimentation; and 2) more advanced applications of AM parts with spatially-varying microstructural features and mechanical properties can be achieved by dynamically changing the process parameters during the build process.  The proposed activities for education and outreach included: 1) two new graduate courses in mechanics and design of AM materials, 2) several senior design projects for undergraduate students, and 3) AM workshop for high school students. These activities aimed to provide training to students in the emerging field of AM as well as to raise the interest level of students in science and engineering, especially those from underrepresented minority groups. The three graduate students and a postdoctoral researcher working on this project were exposed to groundbreaking interdisciplinary research that encompasses AM, mechanics of materials, metallurgy, and heat transfer. 


Last Modified: 10/23/2018
Modified by: Albert C To
